Subject: Re: [neat] Re: grammatical evolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=236201729; y=RqDYXDVDhrPLwZJPDyeqVxM8ldAbJEgeuaE4nLlHMB6d_WoQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: mandor_42

		Hi Ken.,

From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>

> I am not dismissing GE, but I would want to hear an argument
> supporting it more from the encoding and search spaces side rather
> than from the formal languages side.

I think you mix two concepts: the tool used to express encodings and
the encoding.

Any encoding will be expressed in a form and I think you will agree
that this form should be as formal as possible. A formal way to
express encodings would allow us to rely on a solid basis as we would
be able to reproduce experiments more easily and to draw a real
picture of what our encoding is (instead of relying on poorly defined
concepts, figures, etc. to explain our work). For instance, a formal
framework should make easy to define variants of a same encoding to
efficiently understand which biasesre useful for a given class of
problems. Moreover, once we have a good formalism, we can often think
about more complex and abstract concepts.

It's clear that the ideal formalism should allow to express any
encoding: it's a tool to explore encodings (at least a family of
encodings) and to modify the search space.

Overall, I think that designing such a formalism would be a decisive
step to make future progress in our field because we really need a
more solid basis.

So, the next question is: which formalism? We proposed (in the linked
paper) to use attribute grammars and operators inspired by genetic
programming. They are powerful and many concepts can be easily
expressed. For example it's easy to define a direct-encoding for
neural-networks. Howerver, some neuro-evolution systems (especially
NEAT) cannot be fully described because they are not only encodings
(e.g. in NEAT, there's the diversity preservation mechanism). I'm
really not sure that it's the best possible formalism but it's almost
the only one I know.

In the previously linked paper, we designed a modular and hierarchical
encoding with this formalism (i.e. we designed a specific
grammar). This shows at least that it's possible to express such
concepts in the formalism. As a consequence, we now have a
hierarchical and modular encoding and we can ask the next question
(the one you ask): are these features really needed in an encoding?
Our first results show that it can lead to interesting results but
it's not a definitive answer. The point is to have a solid tool to
investigate this question.

Best regards,
-- 
Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
http://animatlab.lip6.fr/~mouret
